data.title: How do you develop compelling characters and arcs in nonlinear storytelling in film?
data.meta_description: Learn how to develop engaging characters and arcs in nonlinear storytelling in film with these tips on structure, transitions, cues, and more.
data.text:
Before you start playing with the structure of your story, you need to have a clear idea of who your characters are, what they want, and why they want it. This will help you create consistent and believable actions and reactions for them, regardless of when and how they appear in the story. You can use tools like character profiles, backstory, dialogue, and personality traits to flesh out your characters and make them relatable and memorable.

When it comes to non-linear storytelling, be aware that your characters' motivations will likely change over time. This means you need to be crystal clear on where they are at in their arc at this point in time. For example, a character may be doggedly chasing a goal, only to become jaded. A flashback will take you to a time when they are focused on the goal whereas a flash forward will see them with a different motivation.

Many characters and characters arcs have become derivates, tropes, or just overused, and the solution to that is defining new, modern, complex issues and coming up with creative ways to tell new stories through new characters. Coming up with a complex character is not enough to be compelling on its on, and their arcs should represent that complexity instead.

There are different types of nonlinear structures that you can use to tell your story, such as flashbacks, flash-forwards, parallel timelines, reverse chronology, or circular narrative. Each one has its own advantages and disadvantages, depending on the genre, theme, tone, and purpose of your story. You should choose a structure that enhances your characters' arcs and conflicts, rather than distracts or confuses the audience. For example, if you want to show how your characters change over time, you can use flashbacks or flash-forwards to contrast their past and present selves. If you want to create suspense or mystery, you can use reverse chronology or circular narrative to reveal information gradually or unexpectedly.

One of the biggest challenges of nonlinear storytelling is maintaining clarity and coherence for the audience. You don't want them to get lost or frustrated by the jumps and shifts in time and space. To avoid this, you need to establish clear transitions and cues that signal when and where the story is moving. You can use visual, auditory, or textual elements, such as colors, sounds, titles, dates, locations, or symbols, to indicate the changes in the timeline. You can also use repetition, foreshadowing, or callbacks to create connections and patterns between different scenes and events.

Nonlinear storytelling can be a powerful way to add depth and dimension to your story, but it can also be a risky one if you overdo it. You don't want to make your story so complex and convoluted that it becomes incomprehensible or boring for the audience. You need to balance the complexity of your structure with the simplicity of your plot and characters. You can do this by focusing on the core message and theme of your story, and by keeping your characters' goals and motivations clear and consistent. You can also use humor, emotion, or action to keep the audience engaged and entertained.

This is something I have seen many amateur and even some professional writers struggle with. Either the story is simplified to the point of insulting the audience's intelligence or the story is complex beyond comprehension. While there's nothing wrong with simple or complex storytelling, I think coherency is the core element in both simple and complex nonlinear storytelling.

Finally, you need to test and refine your story to make sure it works as a nonlinear narrative. You can do this by getting feedback from other writers, readers, or viewers, and by checking for any gaps, errors, or inconsistencies in your story. You can also use tools like outlines, timelines, or diagrams to visualize and organize your story and its structure. You should be willing to revise and edit your story until it achieves the desired effect and impact on the audience.

This article is about linear films which express a story in a non-linear way. In learning and development, non-linear, interactive drama is quite common. In this context, the challenge is to balance analytical thinking with emotional engagement to maintain immersion. Short multiple-choice questions and clips can encourage flow. Dramatic foregrounding can keep viewers critically engaged while maintaining distance from the action. The list of learning points should be short and the branching structure should encourage exploration of content. A linear introduction to establish character, setting, and story can be considered. Points-driven gamification should be avoided as it encourages seeking the most efficient path through the content.
